image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives About this object

profileText: A Delegate from the District of Columbia; born in Washington, D.C., February 6, 1933; attended Washington (D.C.) public schools; graduated from Dunbar High School, Washington, D.C., 1952; B.A., Virginia Union University, Richmond, Va., 1955; B.D., Yale University Divinity School, 1958; pastor, New Bethel Baptist Church, 1959 to present; founder and director, Model Inner City Community Organization, 1966-1972; director, Washington Bureau, Southern Christian Leadership Conference, 1960-1971; vice chairman, District of Columbia City Council, 1967-1969; vice chairman, White House Conference to Fulfill These Rights, 1966; national coordinator, Poor People's Campaign, 1969; chairman, board of directors, Martin Luther King, Jr., Center for Social Change, Atlanta, Ga.; member, Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, 1961-1971; delegate, Democratic National Convention, 1972; elected as a Democrat a Delegate to the Ninety-second Congress, by special election, March 23, 1971; reelected to the nine succeeding Congresses (March 23, 1971-January 3, 1991); was not a candidate for renomination to the One Hundred Second Congress in 1990 but was an unsuccessful candidate for nomination for mayor of Washington, D.C.; is a resident of Washington, D.C.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Ralph Nader Congress Project. Citizens Look at Congress: Walter E. Fauntroy, Democratic Representative from District of Columbia. Washington, D. C.: Grossman Publishers, 1972.

"Walter Edward Fauntroy" in Black Americans in Congress, 1870-2007. Prepared under the direction of the Committee on House Administration by the Office of History & Preservation, U.S. House of Representatives. Washington: Government Printing Office, 2008.

researchRecord.name: ca. 1941-1990, 30 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Part I of former Congressman Walter Fauntroy's papers contain correspondence, news releases, booklets, articles, brochures, statements, meeting files, briefing books, memorabilia, newsletters, photographs, negatives, slides, bills, and hearing files. A finding aid is available in the repository and online.

researchRecord.name: ca. 1940-1990, 715.5 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: Part II of former Congressman Walter Fauntroy's papers include correspondence, news releases, booklets, articles, brochures, statements, meeting files, briefing books, memorabilia, newsletters, photographs, negatives, slides, bills, and hearing files. An inventory is available in the repository. An inventory is available in the repository and online.

researchRecord.name: In the Duke University Chapel Recordings, 1954-2002. 67 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: The collection includes an audiocassette recording of Walter Fauntroy's sermon, “The Social Action Mission of the Church,” from November 22, 1981. A finding aid is available online.

researchRecord.name: 2003, amount unknown.
researchRecord.description: An oral history interview of Walter Fauntroy conducted on January 25, 2003.

researchRecord.name: 1973, 32 pages.
researchRecord.description: In the interview with Walter Fauntroy, he discusses three major influential factors in his life: growing up in segregated Washington, D.C.; theological training; Martin Luther King Jr. He attributes present involvement in politics as an outgrowth of civil rights activities, especially his role as Director, Washington Bureau, Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC). He discusses the National Black Political Convention (1972) and alignment of Blacks with major political parties, and looks at the Congressional Black Caucus, Congressional reaction, and dissension among Caucus members. Fauntroy also comments on home rule for the District of Columbia and the Nixon Administration. No tape available.
